questions.prompt: What is the primary difference between Type 1 and Type 2 hypervisors?
options: Type 1 runs on bare metal, Type 2 runs on a host OS
Type 1 is faster, Type 2 is cheaper
Type 1 is open source, Type 2 is commercial
Type 1 is for Windows, Type 2 is for Linux
questions.explanation: Type 1 hypervisors (bare-metal) run directly on hardware. Type 2 hypervisors (hosted) run as applications on a conventional operating system.

questions.prompt: Paravirtualization requires modification of the guest operating system.
questions.explanation: Paravirtualization modifies the guest OS to cooperate with the hypervisor using hypercalls instead of privileged instructions. Full virtualization runs unmodified guest OS.

questions.prompt: Which technology enables hardware-assisted virtualization on Intel processors?
questions.explanation: Intel VT-x (Virtualization Technology) is the CPU extension that enables hardware-assisted virtualization. AMD's equivalent is AMD-V.

questions.prompt: What is the typical CPU overhead of modern virtualization with hardware support?
questions.explanation: Modern hypervisors with hardware virtualization support (VT-x/AMD-V) introduce only 2-10% CPU overhead, making virtualization very efficient.

questions.prompt: Containers provide stronger isolation than virtual machines because each container has its own kernel.
questions.explanation: Containers share the host OS kernel, providing process-level isolation. VMs have stronger isolation because each VM has its own complete OS and kernel.

questions.prompt: Which hypervisor is used by AWS (historically) and other cloud providers?
questions.explanation: Xen powered AWS EC2 for many years (now transitioning to KVM-based Nitro). Xen is an open-source Type 1 hypervisor designed for cloud environments.

questions.prompt: Live migration (vMotion) allows moving a running VM between hosts without downtime.
questions.explanation: Live migration moves a running VM from one host to another with only milliseconds of downtime. This enables maintenance without service interruption.

questions.prompt: What is memory ballooning used for in virtualization?
questions.explanation: Memory ballooning allows the hypervisor to reclaim unused memory from VMs by inflating a balloon driver in the guest OS, which then releases memory back to the hypervisor.

questions.prompt: Which hypervisor is part of the Linux kernel?
questions.explanation: KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) is built into the Linux kernel, turning Linux into a Type 1 hypervisor. It's used by many cloud providers.

questions.prompt: Thin provisioning allocates full disk space to a VM upfront.
questions.explanation: Thin provisioning allocates disk space on-demand as data is written, improving storage efficiency. Thick provisioning allocates full space upfront.

options: A virtual CPU thread allocated to a VM
questions.explanation: A vCPU (virtual CPU) represents CPU resources allocated to a VM. Each vCPU maps to physical CPU threads/cores, and VMs can have multiple vCPUs.

questions.prompt: Over-subscription means allocating more virtual resources than available physical resources.
questions.explanation: Over-subscription allocates more virtual resources (vCPUs, memory) than physically available, betting that not all VMs will use maximum resources simultaneously.

questions.prompt: Which virtual disk format is used by VMware?
questions.explanation: VMDK (Virtual Machine Disk) is VMware's virtual disk format. VHD is used by Hyper-V, QCOW2 by KVM/QEMU.

questions.prompt: What is the recommended practice for sizing VMs?
options: Start small and scale up based on monitoring
Use fixed 4 vCPU and 16GB RAM for all VMs
questions.explanation: Best practice is to start with minimal resources and scale up based on actual usage monitoring. Over-provisioning wastes resources and can hurt performance.

questions.prompt: Snapshots should be used as a long-term backup solution.
questions.explanation: Snapshots are point-in-time captures for short-term use (testing, updates). They can degrade performance and should not replace proper backups. Delete snapshots after use.
